animal body, in which so wide a range of developmental
variation normally exists. The lower classes of the Vegetable 
Kingdom, however, especially the group of Fungii, afford abundant
examples of it <sup>x</sup>[<u>Note.</u><sup>x</sup> See especially the recent Memoir of M.
Tulasne, in the Annales des Sciences Naturalles]

67  The extreme freedom with which all the cavities of the shell
<s>naturally</s> mutually communicate, is a very marked feature in the structure of
this type; and shows that the several parts of the animal body
are far more closely connected into one whole, than they are in most
of the other Foraminifera whose general plan of conformation
is more or less analogous. Indeed if we were to imagine a
discoidal mass of sarcode to be traversed by a reticulated calcareous
skeleton, somewhat resembling that open areolar texture which
forms the <u>shell</u> of the Echinida, and this network to possess
something of that regularity of the disposition of its successively
formed parts, which is presented to us in the <s>species</s> <u>spines</u> of the Echinida, we should have no unapt representation of <s>its</s> the relation
of the <s>disk of</s> shelly disk of the Orbitolite to the animal which it envelopes. There are certain Sponges
which have a reticulated skeleton composed of mineral matter<s>s</s>
